bibl.note: Transcribed from our own digital image of original manuscript.

add.p: Colored Volunteers.—The First regiment of Kansas Colored volunteers is now full, and has already proved its efficiency. A scheme is now on foot to raise a brigade. Many of the most influential men are interested in the movement, and are using their best efforts to make it successful. Colonel Jennison has been asked to take command of the brigade, and will probably accept the position.

div1.ab: Gen Blunt has ordered the 1st Kansas Colored. (Col Williams) to Baxter's Springs, extreme south eastern portion of Kansas
there is probably going to be work there in Arkansas—
the prize is important there in the rich territories demesnes, the Indian territory, &c. &c

add.p: Colonel E. A. Wild, of the Thirty-fifth Massachusetts regiment, has received a brigadier general's commission, and been empowered to raise a brigade of freedmen to be known as "Wild's African brigade," and to consist of four regiments to be enlisted in North Carolina, and of Colonel Shaw's regiment, now in camp in Massachusetts. General Wild is to appoint his own officers, most of whom will be taken from white regiments now in the service. General Wild is the son of the Rev. Dr. Wild, a clergyman of Brooklyn, a graduate of Harvard, and a regularly educated physician. He served in the Crimea as surgeon in the Turkish army.

div1.note: from Mass. has lost an an arm. is now quite an old Campaigner
